page.title: Pronouns and Proper Names - Pronouns as an NP

form.introduction: Pronouns and also demonstratives, quantifiers, and numbers can stand alone as a nominal phrase in the right context. They cannot normally be modified by possessors, adjectives, or other quantifiers, although they can be modified by a degree word, an article or demonstrative. English examples of this type include the following:
In addition, it is possible to have a pronoun, demonstrative, or quantifier modified by a relative clause, as in:

EnglishExample.exItem: all those who are going with us.
only these two that I saw.

form.introduction: Finally, these categories can also be modified by a partitive phrase (or other PP), as in:
form.instruction:
This distribution can be accounted for if we allow pronouns, demonstratives, quantifiers, and numbers to be NPs (rather than DPs) in the tree structure given at the beginning of
Simple and Possessed Nominal Phrases.

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the optional partitive PP occur with respect to the pronoun, demonstrative, quantifier or number?

form.instruction: The partitive PP is usually headed by a specific preposition or postposition. Mark this pre/post-position with the feature partitive in the lexicon. All others will automatically default to -partitive so those PPs will not be allowed.
